text: - [Mujahid] Hi, I'm Mujahid,

a solution architect
at Amazon Web Services.
In this video, I'm going to demonstrate

how to enable AWS managed
application access

with account instances
of IAM Identity Center.
On the agenda today,

I will give you an overview
of IAM Identity Center.
Next, I will explain the difference
between an organization instance

and an account instance
of IAM Identity Center,

while also highlighting
the use cases for each.
Last, I will demonstrate how customers

can use the account instance
of IAM Identity Center
to enable AWS managed application access
for their workforce.

AWS IAM Identity Center
is the recommended service

for managing your workforce's
access to AWS applications
or multiple AWS accounts or both.

AWS IAM Identity Center
can be used to connect AWS
to your existing identity provider,

such as Microsoft Active
Directory, Azure Entra ID,
JumpCloud, Okta, CyberArk, OneLogin, Ping,
or Google Workspace.
Alternatively, it can also assist you
in creating users directly within AWS.

IAM Identity Center can
be used in conjunction

with your current AWS account-level
access configurations,
providing a seamless integration

with your existing
identity management setup.
Identity Center is now a crucial component
for many AWS applications.
It enables user-centric experiences

that would otherwise be
difficult to achieve.
For instance, it allows human users

to enjoy a seamless
single sign-on experience
across AWS services,

including generative AI
applications like Amazon Q.
Alternatively, if customers would like

to set up a new multi-account
AWS environment,

IAM Identity Center will
be the right service

to manage workforce access to
their AWS accounts as well.

It will help them do this
in one place, consistently,

and at scale, and it will
make it easier to find out
who has access to what.
Finally, it is important to remember

that you can manage application
access, like Amazon Q,
using IAM Identity Center without using it
for multi-account access.

Setting up IAM Identity
Center for application access
would not affect

your existing account-level
access policies.
When you enable IAM Identity Center,
in conjunction with AWS organizations,
we are creating an organization instance
of IAM Identity Center.

An organization instance
is the primary method

of enabling IAM Identity
Center, and in most cases,

an organization instance
is the recommended setup

because they support all
features of IAM Identity Center.

However, sometimes, customers
want to run a temporary trial

of a supported AWS managed
application in a sandbox
or a proof-of-concept environment.

For such use cases, customers
can deploy an account instance
of AIM Identity Center.

Account instances support
isolated deployment
of AWS managed applications
or an OIDC customer-managed application
in a single AWS account,

leveraging AIM Identity
Center, Workforce Identity,
and access portal features.

You can find the list of
AWS managed applications
that support account instance deployment

by scanning the QR code
shown on the screen.

Let's go ahead and see how
you can use account instance
of AIM Identity Center
to enable AWS managed application access
for Workforce Identity in a sandbox
or proof-of-concept environment.
For this demo,

I will create an AWS AIM
Identity Center account instance.
I will choose Okta as my external IdP,

I will enable Amazon
EMR Studio integration

with AWS IAM Identity Center,
and as the final step,

I will log into AWS access
portal using my Okta credentials
for a single sign-on access
to AWS managed application, EMR Studio.

I have now switched over to
the AWS management console.

I've logged into one
of the member accounts
of my AWS organization.
Within this member account, I'm going

to enable account instances
for AWS IAM Identity Center.

To do this, you will go to the
IAM Identity Center Service.
This would be your landing page.
At this point, you'll click on enable.
I'll go ahead and click on enable,
and when I click on enable,

I'll be shown a message by
IAM Identity Center service

that I have the option to
create an organization instance
as well as an account instance.

As I mentioned during the
earlier section of my video,

organization instance is
the recommended method
for AWS IAM Identity Center,
however, for the purpose of this demo,
I'm going to select continue with setup
by creating the account instance.

Only one account instance
can be created per account
for all regions.

I select this radio button,
I'll click on continue,
I'll click on enable, and as you can see,
now I have the account instance
inside AWS AIM Identity Center created.

Although I have the
account instance created,

I still have to go ahead and
configure my identity source.

In this case, I'm going
to follow the instructions

that are provided on
AWS IAM Identity Center

and integrate my account
instance with Okta.

At this point, I'm
going to pause the demo,

complete the setup, and
resume the demo again.
Okay, as you can see on my screen,
my integration with Okta is complete,
and I have users coming in from Okta,
Jennifer Lang in this case.

As a next step, I'm going to
add Amazon managed EMR Studio
as an AWS managed application

that leverages AWS AIM Identity
Center account instance.

For this, I'm going to
search for EMR Studio service
through the EMR service.
After clicking on the EMR service,

I'm going to go to the EMR
Studio section, click on studios.
I'll go ahead and create a new EMR studio.
I'll select the custom option.
I'll provide it a name, a description.

I'll provide it a service
role, EMR Studio access.
I'll leave the workspace name as it is,
and this is the most important section

when it comes to the integration
with AIM Identity Center.
I'll select AWS IAM Identity Center.
I'll select the same service role.

In this case, I'll select
connect to account instance
of IAM Identity Center,

and then I'll leave it
as all users and groups.
I'll leave everything as default.
I'll click on create studio.

So my studio is created,
but none of my users

still have access to EMR
Studio through Identity Center.

To enable this to add my users,
I'll click on select users.
I'll click on get started.

In this, I will search
for my user, Jennifer.
There you go.

I'll click on assign, and
now my user, Jennifer,
can log into EMR Studio
using the AIM Identity Center credentials.

To demonstrate this, I'm going
to go to the Okta login page

and then complete the
authentication process,
and then from there, I'll resume
once I'm on the AWS access portal.

As you can see, I've
completed the login process

through Okta, and as you
can see, on my screen,

in the list of applications
that Jennifer has access to,

there is EMR Studio, one of
the options listed there.
I logged in using my Okta credentials,
and then I was directed
to AWS IAM Identity Center Access Portal.
At this point, I can go ahead
and click on the EMR studio URL,

and this will take me
to the EMR Studio page.

I'm successfully logged
into AWS EMR Studio
as Jennifer Lang.

Let's summarize what we
learned from this demo.

First, we looked at the
differences between organization

and account instance
of AIM Identity Center.

Next, I created an AWS AIM
Identity Center account instance,

integrated that with
Okta as my external IdP,
then I enabled EMR Studio integration
with AWS AIM Identity Center.

Afterwards, I logged into
the AWS access portal

using my Okta credentials
for a single sign-on access
to AWS managed application, EMR Studio.
Now that you have seen how easy it is
to enable AWS managed application access

with account instances
of AIM Identity Center,

here are some more resources
for you to get started.

If you would like to explore
these resources further,

please pause the video at this
point and scan the QR code.
Thank you.
